title: RL31919
content: According to the Federal Trade Commission, identity theft is the most common complaint from consumers in all 50 states, accounting for over 35% of the total number of complaints received for calendar years 2004-2006. In 2006, out of 674,354 complaints, 36% were related to identity theft. The misuse of victim's information included credit card fraud (25%), phone/utilities fraud (16%), bank fraud (16%), employment-related fraud (14%), government documents/benefits fraud (5%), loan fraud (5%), and other types of fraud (24%). Identity theft can result in damaged credit records and unauthorized charges. Identity theft complaints include fraud related to government documents or benefits, loan fraud, and other types of fraud. Victims may experience damaged credit records, unauthorized charges on credit cards, and unauthorized withdrawals from bank accounts. Changing telephone numbers, social security numbers, and addresses may be necessary. Concerns about identity theft are increasing due to data security breaches. Federal laws can assist victims in removing inaccurate information from credit records and imposing criminal penalties on identity thieves. The Identity Theft Assumption Deterrence Act includes laws to help victims of identity theft remove inaccurate information from credit records and unauthorized charges from credit accounts. It also imposes criminal penalties on those who assume another person's identity using fraudulent identification documents. Certain offenses under the statute directly relate to consumer identity theft, allowing impostors to be prosecuted. The statute criminalizes the production, possession, and use of false identification documents, as well as the transfer or use of another person's identification without lawful authority. Punishments vary depending on the specific offense, with fines or imprisonment of up to 15 years possible. The punishment for offenses involving fraud related to identification documents varies depending on the specific offense and the type of document involved. Penalties range from fines or imprisonment of up to 15 years for using another person's identification to terms of imprisonment up to twenty-five years for offenses related to international terrorism. The Identity Theft Penalty Enhancement Act, signed in 2004, defines penalties for aggravated identity theft under Title 18 of the United States Code. Aggravated identity theft occurs when a person unlawfully uses another person's identification during certain felonies, resulting in a two-year imprisonment in addition to the original felony punishment. Offenses related to terrorism can lead to additional penalties. The Identity Theft Penalty Enhancement Act of 2004 increases penalties for identity theft, including a two-year imprisonment for aggravated identity theft in addition to the original felony punishment. Offenses related to terrorism can result in an additional five-year imprisonment. The act also directs the United States Sentencing Commission to adjust guidelines to appropriately punish identity theft offenses. Additionally, the act authorizes appropriations to the Justice Department for investigating and prosecuting identity theft cases. The Identity Theft Penalty Enhancement Act of 2004 increases penalties for identity theft, including imprisonment for aggravated identity theft and additional punishment for offenses related to terrorism. It authorizes appropriations to the Justice Department for investigating and prosecuting identity theft cases. The Fair Credit Reporting Act offers victims assistance in removing negative information resulting from unauthorized charges or accounts from their credit files. It outlines consumer rights regarding credit reports and permissible uses of information. The Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) outlines consumer rights regarding credit reports, permissible uses of information, and imposes duties on consumer reporting agencies to ensure accuracy. Consumers can file suit for violations, such as inaccurate information disclosure. The Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) allows consumers to sue credit reporting agencies for failing to verify the accuracy of information in reports or disclosing inaccurate information due to identity theft. The FACT Act, signed in 2003, includes amendments to prevent identity theft and create a national standard for addressing consumer concerns. The Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) and the FACT Act aim to prevent identity theft and assist victims by creating national standards. New provisions require credit card issuers to follow procedures for address changes and truncation of account numbers on receipts. Consumers can request truncation of social security numbers on credit reports and have fraud alerts placed in their files. The new provisions under the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) and the FACT Act allow consumers to request fraud alerts to be placed in their credit files for 90 days, with the option to extend it for up to seven years. The fraud alert is shared with all users of the credit report and must be included in any credit score generated. Victims of identity theft can also request the truncation of social security numbers on credit reports. Victims of identity theft can request fraud alerts to be placed in their credit files, which must be included in any credit score generated. They can also have fraudulent information blocked from their credit reports by providing proof of identity theft. Requests for blocking information related to identity theft must be referred to other consumer reporting agencies. Victims of identity theft can request information about the alleged crime. Businesses must provide transaction records to victims or law enforcement agencies investigating identity theft upon request and verification of identity. The Fair Credit Billing Act allows consumers to dispute unauthorized charges made by impostors. The Fair Credit Billing Act (FCBA) allows consumers to dispute unauthorized charges, including charges made by impostors. It aims to protect consumers against inaccurate credit billing practices by providing a procedure for resolving billing errors in consumer credit transactions. Consumers can file a claim with the creditor to have billing errors resolved, and they are not required to pay the disputed amount until the issue is resolved. The Fair Credit Billing Act (FCBA) allows consumers to dispute unauthorized charges and file claims with creditors to resolve billing errors. Consumers are not required to pay disputed amounts until issues are resolved, and creditors must investigate and correct any billing errors. The Electronic Fund Transfer Act provides a mechanism for challenging unauthorized transactions and having accounts recredited. The Electronic Fund Transfer Act (EFTA) allows consumers to challenge unauthorized transactions and limits their liability for such transfers. If a consumer reports a loss or theft of their card within two business days, their liability is limited to $50 or the amount of unauthorized transfers before reporting. The Electronic Fund Transfer Act (EFTA) limits consumer liability for unauthorized transfers to $50 or the amount of unauthorized transfers before reporting a loss or theft of a card. Financial institutions must provide documentation of electronic fund transfers and investigate any errors reported by consumers within 60 days. The Electronic Fund Transfer Act (EFTA) limits consumer liability for unauthorized transfers to $50 or the amount of unauthorized transfers before reporting a loss or theft of a card. Financial institutions must investigate errors reported by consumers within 60 days and correct any errors within one day of determination. If an error is found, the institution must recredit the consumer's account and provide results within 10 business days. The President's Identity Theft Task Force recommended a plan to crack down on criminals trafficking in stolen identities, strengthen protection of personal information, educate consumers and businesses on safeguarding themselves, and improve data security to prevent identity theft. The Plan recommended by the President's Identity Theft Task Force aims to enhance data security, educate consumers, assist victims, and deter identity theft through aggressive prosecution. Recommendations include amending statutes to prosecute identity thieves targeting corporations, adding new crimes for aggravated identity theft, and closing gaps in federal laws. Amend identity theft and aggravated identity theft statutes to prosecute thieves targeting corporations and organizations. Add new crimes for aggravated identity theft and eliminate requirements for theft of electronic data. Penalize creators of malicious spyware and keyloggers. Enhance sentences for identity thieves affecting multiple victims. Department of Homeland Security published final rule for State-issued driver's licenses in accordance with REAL ID Act of 2005. The Department of Homeland Security published the final rule for State-issued driver's licenses and identification cards in accordance with the REAL ID Act of 2005. The Real ID Rule establishes standards for issuing identification documents, including security features, proof of identity, and verification of source documents. States can request extensions until December 31, 2009 if they meet certain security benchmarks. The Real ID Rule sets security standards for issuing licenses and identification cards. States can request extensions until December 31, 2009, and those meeting benchmarks can get a second extension until May 10, 2011. States must replace all licenses with REAL ID-compliant cards by December 1, 2014, for people born after December 1, 1964, and by December 1, 2017, for those born on or before December 1, 1964. The rule is effective March 31, 2008.
